question:
Subtitle: The First Roman Emperor
Reign: 27 BCE-14 CE
Notes: Julius Caesar's adopted son, defeated Mark Antony and Cleopatra, benevolent, stable period - Pax Romana, claimed land in Europe and Asia Minor, expanded infrastructure and art, named a month after himself

Subtitle: The Reluctant Leader
Reign: 14-37 CE
Notes: Successor to Augustus, miserable, paranoid, reluctant to rule, talented military commander, later a harsh dictator, murdered/mistreated Senators, retreated for semi-retirement on the island of Capri

Subtitle: The Tyrant
Reign: 37-41 CE
Notes: Tyrannical, indulgent, excessive, brutally assassinated, likened himself to a god, committed murder/adultery/barbarism acrosss Rome, built 3 mile floating bridge across Naples to ride his horse which he later named consulate, replaced statue heads with his own

Subtitle: The Unexpected Hero
Reign: 41-54 CE
Notes: Spastic paralysis, epilepsy, remarkable scholar in seclusion (knowledge of history and government), ingenuous, conquered Britan - honored with trimphal arch on the Via Flaminia

Subtitle: The Colossus
Reign: 54-69 CE
Notes: Emperor at 17, supported arts, lowered taxes, public games held every 5 years, later murdered dissenters (even his mother), blamed for burning of Rome - new 100-acre palace in its place with 100-ft statue in the center (Colossus of <Name>), suicide

Subtitle: New Morality
Reign: 69-79 CE
Notes: Flavian dynasty, restored Rome's former glory after Nero, discipline, higher taxes, moral, invested money in improving public life with infrastructure (bathhouses, Temple of Peace, and the Colosseum)

Subtitle: Expanding the Empire
Reign: 98-117 CE
Notes: Expanded eastward into Dacia, Arabia, and Armenia; grew empire to largest ever by far, building program including namesake Forum, Market, and Column

Subtitle: A Man of the People
Reign: 117-138 CE
Notes: Stability, peace, 'people's king' - visited every Roman province, ate with troops, astute negotiator (suppressed Jewish Revolt of 130-136 CE), withdrew troops (Iraq and others), namesake Wall marking Roman Empire across Northern England, buildings - Parthenon, Temple of Venus, Roma

Subtitle: The Philosopher
Reign: 161-180 CE
Notes: 'Platonic King' concept from Plato's Republic, generally peaceful, defended Roman territory in the Marcomannic Wars, Stoic Philosophy, series of essays called Meditations (wise and honorable living), last of the 'Five Good Emperors'

Subtitle: The Cruel Gladiator
Reign: 161-192 CE
Notes: Marcus Aurelius's son, cruelest Emperor, spoiled, indulgent, killed for sport as Gladitor against weak foes (Herculean garb with lion skin), arrogant - named himself Hercules and tried to name himself a living god, Roman financial ruin and civil war that eventually ended the Empire

Subtitle: The Army Man
Reign: 193-211 CE
Notes: Severan Dynasty, accomplished general, African descent, grew army (higher wages and ability to marry), expanded Roman (5 million sq km - largest ever), buildings - Triumphal Arch in the Roman Forum, Septizodium in Rome

Subtitle: Cruel and Merciless
Reign: 198-217 CE
Notes: Son of Septimus Severus, cruel, had his fellow Emperor brother killed and removed from memorabilia, granted all free people Roman citizenship to collect more taxes, modeled himself after Alexander the Great, died fighting the Parthians

Subtitle: Brute Force
Reign: 235-238 CE
Notes: Tall, large, strong, size gave him an advantage in the army - quickly rose, Senate despised his brutish barbarism but scared to challenge him, won long feud with Germanic tribes to become Germanicus Maximus

Subtitle: Prisoner and Slave
Reign: 253-260 CE
Notes: Crisis of the Third Century - foreign invasion threatened security, left son Gallienus the west side of the Empire for more control, taken prisoner by Persian King Shapur in Battle of Edessa, after that - slave, human footstool, died being forced to swallow liquid gold

Subtitle: The Thirty Tyrants
Reign: 253-268 CE
Notes: Took throne following father Valerian's horrible death, weak, timid, Greece attacked by Goths who burned the city, Shapur (Persian King) claimed Syria and Asia, toppled by an uprising - string of successors vied for power (30 Tyrants), before suspicious death repelled Goth invasion and defeated the Alamanni

Subtitle: The Great, The Christian
Reign: 306-337 CE
Notes: Fought previous tetrarchy of huge and unwieldy landmass to seize control, accepted Christianity as dominant religion for Roman society, imperial/Christian capital in Constantinople - led to Empire's split (Byzantine - East, Middle Ages - West)
